Case Notes Section 368 [sic], which was quite similar to Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), found to be the most &ldquo;analogous&rdquo; state statute regarding applicable limitations period for plaintiff&rsquo;s ADA claim; since statutory period of ninety days was appropriately &ldquo;borrowed&rdquo; and became part of plaintiff&rsquo;s ADA claim, and since plaintiff filed suit within this time period, plaintiff&rsquo;s claim was not time-barred under ADA limitations period; passenger ticket contract did not trump applicable state law and ADA limitations periods. 51 F. Supp. 2d 1057 (1999). Plaintiff&rsquo;s [chapters] 368 and 378 state law claims against the county were time-barred under §46-72, where plaintiff never provided the county written notice of plaintiff&rsquo;s claim. 504 F. Supp. 2d 969 (2007). Plaintiff&rsquo;s charges filed with the equal employment opportunity commission were deemed &ldquo;dual-filed&rdquo; with the Hawaii civil rights commission. Plaintiff timely filed the charge for claims under chapter 378 based on plaintiff&rsquo;s termination within the 180-day time limitation. 907 F. Supp. 2d 1143 (2012).
